notable_quotes.speaker: Henry Claudon
notable_quotes.english: a bad reputation for being wicked

notable_quotes.speaker: Remy Grand Demenge (advice to Jennon)
notable_quotes.french: la rompre ny appliquer a la question
notable_quotes.english: break her or apply her to the question (torture)
notable_quotes.context: Advising her to confess freely rather than be tortured

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Loys (gaoler to Jennon)
notable_quotes.french: que ce n'estoit encore rien le question qu'elle avoit soufferte que sy elle estoit condampnée a l'extraordinaire que c'estoit pour l'endurer trois fois le jour, ou bien trois jours durantz
notable_quotes.english: that the torture she had suffered was nothing compared to what she would endure if condemned to the extraordinary torture - three times a day or for three days
notable_quotes.context: Gaoler trying to persuade her to confess

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Zabey
notable_quotes.french: pour aveugler ceux auxquelz elle auroit causé desplaisir sortilegicquement sur leurs bestiaulx
notable_quotes.english: to blind those to whom she had caused harm through sorcery on their animals
notable_quotes.context: Suggestion put to her about the prayer for healing animals

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Jean Goudel (witness 8)
notable_quotes.context: Jennon allegedly called a pig 'peroquet' as she passed, and it died

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Mongeat Vergier
notable_quotes.english: being unable to be patient any longer
notable_quotes.context: When his child became ill after eating Jennon's apple

economic_context.details: Multiple witnesses (6, 8, 9) testified about a quarrel between Jennon, her husband Jean Zabey, and the father of Remy Grand Demenge over share of a house. The father was not willing to take the price offered for his half. This property dispute led to a 12-16 year illness (accounts vary) and suspicions of witchcraft.

legal_context.redress_outcome: Took no action over accusations of being witch because she had no witnesses
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Jennon said she was tired of being in prison; gaolers tried to persuade her to confess; she wished she was by a warm fire

change_de_nancy.modification_details: 17 May 1608: Approved torture with moderation for age. 4 June 1608: Rejected request for further torture on grounds that indices were not sufficient, and recommended she be renvoyée (released). However, local court tortured her again on 18 June before finally releasing her on 20 June.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a significant trial that ended in release rather than execution. Jennon Zabey endured torture twice (23 May with thumbscrews and rack, 18 June with thumbscrews only) but never confessed. The Change de Nancy rejected request for further torture on 4 June 1608, stating indices were not sufficient and recommending release. However, she was tortured again on 18 June before final release on 20 June 1608. Key features: extensive testimony about her witch reputation spanning 7-15 years; multiple animal deaths and human deaths attributed to her; pattern of quarrels followed by harms; she admitted only to knowing a prayer for healing animals taught by her mother. Age discrepancy: claimed to be 90 but later revealed to be approximately 60. Notable that she maintained denials throughout and survived.
